title.rendered: New Logo and Packaging for Lars Monsen by Strømme Throndsen Design

content.rendered:
Establis… I mean, born in 1963, Lars Monsen is a Sámi-Norwegian full-time adventurer who has made a name for himself from his expeditions and resulting documentaries — the most well-known probably being his 2-year, 7-month trek across northern Canada. From his multiple hikes, canoe trips, and dogsled runs, Lars has gathered enough experience and fans to write over 18 books. His next frontier is product branding, partnering with existing outdoor brands he has used and vetted to create new products made to his specifications; from a new line of underwear garments with Komplettfritid to an upcoming range of knives with Brussleto. Last month, Lars introduced a new logo designed by Oslo, Norway-based Strømme Throndsen Design

A sans-serif simplicity, limited colour palette and unique monogram blends technology and individuality with a reference to the steep climb of a mountain face. Paired with a strong portrait image, capturing Lars’ familiar and climate hardened image and tinted red, our solution is expressive and communicative at any size and within any context.

Provided text

The old logo was kind of amazing, in a kitschy, unfocused way and more appropriate for an astronaut than a nature rover like Lars. The new logo features a clever “LM” monogram that looks like much of the stencil lettering and red-orange color you find silkscreened on the side of outdoor products (or at least on our REI-bought tent). The nod to a steep mountain climb also comes through with the sloped “L”. The wordmark, unfortunately, doesn’t have any of the personality that the monogram has and even if it’s meant to play a supporting role it feels too “default”. I’m even surprised it’s not Circular by Lineto because that’s what everything is these days.

In application, the identity is quite straightforward focusing on Lars’ distinctive face that looks even more rugged and awesome as a duotone. Paired with the bright monogram against black, the packaging is not the most innovative or fanciest of designs, but when you want to trek through Alaska what you want is simple, bold, and encouraging… traits captured perfectly by Lars’ facial hair and parka.
